channel.title: dotNET Weekly - Week undefined Year undefined

item.title: C# 9.0 Primary constructors
item.content:encoded: C# 9.0 now introduces a new simplified way to construct your classes. Most constructors are very redundant as the arguments of the constructor map one to one with a property of the same name. There's now a way to get rid of all that extra code.

item.title: Blazor GameDev – part 8: keyboard input
item.content:encoded: Hi everyone! Welcome back to part 8 of our Blazor 2d Gamedev series. Today we’re going to refactor our last example, detecting keyboard input to control character animations.

item.title: Scaling relational SQL databases
item.content:encoded: Many applications today still rely on traditional SQL databases like MySQL, MariaDb or PostgreSQL for data storage and data processing. With the growing amount of data and new workloads that are made with these database systems, we often find ourselves in situations where we need to think about scaling such systems.

item.title: Redis Caching in ASP.NET Core!
item.content:encoded:
Redis Caching in ASP.NET Core!
Here are the topics covered. 1. What is Distributed Caching in ASP.NET Core? 2. Pros & Cons of Distributed Caching 3. IDistributedCache interface 4. What is Redis? 5. Setting up Redis on Windows 10 6. Getting to know Redis Better 7. Redis CLI Commands 8. Integrating Redis Caching in ASP.NET Core

item.title: Introducing C# 9: Extending Partial Methods
item.content:encoded:
C# 8 (and above) has some restrictions regarding partial methods. For example :
- Partial methods must have a void return type - Partial methods can’t have out parameters - Partial methods can’t have any accessibility keyword (public, private, protected etc….)
C# 9 aims to remove these restrictions. If you want to learn more about the motivation behind this, you can find a good description on the Github page here: https://github.com/jaredpar/csharplang/blob/partial/proposals/extending-partial-methods.md
